authorization code to enroll.  There is space in the classroom now.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>You may also substitute one quarter of
any other ICS research seminar (e.g., </p>

style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

</div>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Place:
<a href="http://www.classrooms.uci.edu/GAC/ICS259.html">ICS-259</a> (building <a
href="http://www.classrooms.uci.edu/GAC/ICS.html">302</a> on the <a
href="http://today.uci.edu/pdf/UCI_10_map_campus_core.pdf">UCI campus map</a><span
class=GramE>)</span><br>
Time: Wednesday 10:00-10:50am <o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Faculty research lectures:
Co-located with ICS-90, Wednesday 4:00-5:00pm, <a
href="http://www.classrooms.uci.edu/GAC/EH1200.html">EH-1200</a> (<a
href="http://www.classrooms.uci.edu/GAC/EH.html">building 308</a> on the <a
href="http://today.uci.edu/pdf/UCI_10_map_campus_core.pdf">UCI campus map</a>)<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>[NOTE: Some ICS-90 meetings will not
involve faculty research lectures, and can be skipped.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>See schedule as it develops (available
at the bottom of <a href="http://www.ics.uci.edu/~pattis/ICS-90/index.html">this
URL</a>). The faculty research lectures are 4-4:30pm and 4:30-5pm, which you
are obliged to attend if possible.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>The time slot 5-5:20pm is reserved for advice to freshmen, which you may
skip.]<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Two
people primarily oversee the ICS Honors Program. The <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>Honors Program Advisor,</i> currently Rick Lathrop, is the faculty
member in charge of the program. The <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>Honors
Program Counselor,</i> currently Jessica Shanahan, will help orient students
and track their progress. Feel free to ask us any questions about the Honors
Program.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Instructor/ICS Honors Program
Advisor: Richard Lathrop <br>
Office hours: Wednesdays 11:00am-12:20pm, or anytime by appointment, in
DBH-4224<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Email:<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span><a
href="mailto:rickl@uci.edu?subject=ICS-H197:%20%3cplease%20edit%20Subject%3e">rickl@uci.edu</a><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>(If you send email, please put
“ICS-H197” somewhere in the Subject line.)<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p> </o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>ICS Honors Program Counselor:
Jessica Shanahan <br>
Office hours: By appointment, in ICS-</span><span class=tabledata><span
style='font-size:12.0pt'>352</span></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Email: <a
href="mailto:shanahan@uci.edu?subject=ICS-H197:%20%3cplease%20edit%20Subject%3e">shanahan@uci.edu</a><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>(If you send email, please put
“ICS-H197” somewhere in the Subject line.)<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=left>

</span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:red'>Goal:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black'>ICS H197 provides an opportunity for undergraduate honors students
in the Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences to learn about
the research taking place in the School and to begin to get involved with this
research. The major purpose of this course is to help you learn what sort of
research is going on, which people do what, and how to get connected with a
research project. The course will also provide a general introduction to the
scientific and technical research enterprise, including the research
literature, research IP and entrepreneurship, how to give a successful
technical talk, and the responsible conduct of research</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>. Various
enrichment activities include a library-based introduction to searching the
research literature, faculty panel on improving your graduate school applications,
and the opportunity to practice and improve technical talk presentation skills
in a live talk to the class.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>One
of your major goals in this course is to gain an understanding of what research
is being pursued in the School and what areas might be of interest to you for
your project. This is <span class=GramE>crucial,</span> since it should help
you complete your second goal, selection of your faculty advisor. Remember that
the arrangement must be mutually acceptable, so there is no guarantee that the
first faculty member you talk to will say yes; it may be, for example, that
they have no suitable project in mind at the time you ask.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>It
is not imperative that you begin your research immediately next quarter if your
schedule for graduation allows you enough time. However, there are some
important advantages to starting fairly soon, and we encourage you to begin by
spring quarter. Starting early gives you more flexibility with regard to
finishing the rest of your degree requirements, especially if you want to
continue the research for more than two quarters. Also, students often find
that those faculty members who have supervised their honors research project
are good sources for letters of recommendation; they will be in the best
position to comment on your ability if you are well into your research project.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=left>

</span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:red'>Please Note:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo4'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>(1)<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>Two types of students take this course: students
in the ICS Honors Program (ICSHP), and students in the <span class=SpellE>Campuswide</span>
Honors Program (CHP). In many ways the requirements are the same for both types
of students: you are to select a faculty advisor, do two or more quarters of
research with that advisor, and produce a report which is considered to be of
honors quality. However, students in the <span class=SpellE>Campuswide</span>
Honors Program should discuss their plans with counselors in the CHP, in order
to make sure that they are meeting the requirements of that program.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo4'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>(2)<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>You should attend one or the other of your
choice of these two departmental research seminars:<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-top:5.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:
.5in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span class=SpellE><span class=GramE><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'>CompSci</span></span></span><span
class=GramE><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black'><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>200S</span></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>      </span>SEM IN COMPSCI
RSCH<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>     </span>F
11:00-11:50<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:5.0pt;margin-left:
.5in'><span class=GramE><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>In4matx<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>209S</span></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>      </span>SEMINAR
INFORMATICS<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>      
</span>F<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>3:00- 3:50p<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>You must attend at least one quarter of at least
one of these seminars to qualify for the ICS Honors Program.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>You should do so this quarter; but if
you have a schedule conflict, you may attend during the first quarter in which
you do not have a schedule conflict.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Please let me know if you are unable to attend this quarter.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo4'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>(3)<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>We are in the process of transitioning the ICS
H197 class into a more flexible largely-online course oriented more along the
lines of "Introduction to Undergraduate Research."<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please help develop and debug the new
format and content.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>We'll work out
the details as we go along.</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:red'>Class Setup:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>This
course is graded Pass/Not Pass, and the principal formal requirement is that
you attend and participate. You must read (at least) one research paper by an
ICS faculty member, and attend (at least) one ICS research seminar, CS-200S or
In4matx-209S.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Some
of the class exercises may involve students giving feedback to fellow students,
and your active participation is necessary for everyone to get the most benefit
from this. Occasional absences are inevitable given busy schedules, and will be
excused on a case-by-case basis; make sure you sign the attendance sheet each
class period you attend.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:red'>ICS H198: Honors Research<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>To
complete the honors program you must do two quarters of independent, supervised
work (ICS 198) with your faculty advisor. (In some cases, your advisor might
ask you to take a graduate course to substitute for the first quarter.) Passing
the 198s does not necessarily guarantee successful completion of the honors
program, however. For the ICSHP, the thesis report on your honors work must be
certified by your faculty advisor and by the program advisor to be of honors
quality. (Again, students in the CHP should keep in touch with counselors in
that program about the requirements.)<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

ICS or CS can count completion of two ICS H198s as one project course.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:

style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>five grad schools you might apply
to.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>For each school, identify one
professor there with whom you might work.<o:p></o:p></span></u></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo12'><![if !supportLists]><span

color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Email <span style='color:black'>your
list to Dr. Lathrop by Wed., 24 Oct.</span><span style='color:#0033BB'><o:p></o:p></span></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-left:1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo12'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>The reason for this requirement is so that when you write your
Statement of Purpose for each school, you will be able to mention at least one
professor<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> *from that school* </b>who
interests you.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-left:1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo12'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>Some professors will do a global string search for their name
through all of the applicant's Statements of Purpose, and then preferentially
read those applications that mention their name.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo12'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>Thus, if you want to improve the chances that your application
actually will be read seriously, it is helpful to you to mention names of
professors at that school who interest you.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Of course, if you mention a long list of
names it will be obvious spam, so mention no more than one to three. Also,
briefly mention something personal that attracts your interest about each,
again to indicate that it isn’t just impersonal spam.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>You learned the basics in
kindergarten:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t lie,
don’t cheat, <span class=GramE>don’t</span> steal.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>*
Don’t lie:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t make
up false data or otherwise falsify results.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>*
Don’t cheat:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t
misrepresent your data as something it is not or as better than it is.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>*
Don’t steal:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t use
the words or data of others without proper credit and citation; don’t
plagiarize.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>More complicated cases may require you to
consult for advice and disclose conflicts of interest so they can be managed.<o:p></o:p></b></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
2'>                        </span><span
style='color:red'>When in doubt, seek advice and disclose conflicts.</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><o:p> </o:p></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
4'>                                                </span></span></b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Influence Analysis <span class=GramE>Through</span>
Twitter Connectivity Mapping [<a href="DrakeTetreault%20-%20HonorsPresentation.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></b></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>Social
media sites such as Twitter increasingly dominate the information dissemination
market which was previously the realm of television and newspaper. Analyzing
trends in social media is made <span class=SpellE>made</span> more difficult
than analyzing traditional media because of the ability of social media
participants to subscribe to as many information sources as desired, increasing
the potential number of inter-user links from linear in the number of users to
quadratic. For my research project I will implement a web crawler that continuously
queries Twitter use data from that site's public API and organizes the data
into a two dimensional influence map that depicts the relationships and
importance of various Twitter accounts. This representation will facilitate
analysis of the predominant information sources available to the modern
internet user.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
2'>                        </span>10:25-10:50
--- <span class=SpellE>Gio</span> <span class=SpellE>Borje</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Combinatorial
Game Representation and Analysis of Snort [<a href="borje_presentation.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>The game
of a Snort is a partisan, combinatorial game where solving which player has a
winning strategy is a PSPACE-complete problem. We analyze the game of Snort by
describing <span class=GramE>a state space prove</span> that the game is
unfair. However, rather than solving the game for general graphs, we
demonstrate generalized winning strategies for a few common families of graphs
such as star graphs, path graphs and cycle graphs.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><o:p> </o:p></p>

2'>                        </span>10:00-10:25
--- Jay Tolentino<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:</span></b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:4'>                                                </span>Crowdsourcing
and Aggregating Visual Design Critique [<a
href="CrowdsourcedCritique_jtolentino.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>Crowdsourcing
has been growing rapidly both in its efficiency and potential in managing and
leveraging <span class=SpellE>microtasks</span>. In particular, there is the
possibility of exchanging detailed, in-depth feedback with <span class=SpellE>crowdworkers</span>
of varied demographical backgrounds. In the case of visual designers, feedback
in real life is often limited to a designer's circle of acquaintances. The <span
class=SpellE>CrowdCrit</span> <span class=GramE>systems developed by the
Human-Computer Interaction Institute of Carnegie Mellon utilizes</span> the
opinions available through crowdsourcing in order to provide more varied
feedback for the designers. The biggest challenge of the project <span
class=GramE>is understanding</span> how to scaffold the system in order to
yield helpful feedback for designers. After extensive prototyping of the
critique aggregation interface, the full system was finished the summer of 2013
and a multistage user study was conducted to better understand the <span
class=GramE>system 's</span> overall helpfulness for designers.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
2'>                        </span>10:25-10:50
--- Jonathan Stroud and <span class=SpellE>Igii</span> <span class=SpellE>Enverga</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
4'>                                                </span></span></b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Ensemble Learning and the Heritage
Health Prize [<a href="stroud_enverga_presentation.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>The
Heritage Health Prize is awarded to the team that develops the most accurate
model for predicting how long a person will spend in the hospital during the
next year, given a set of historical medical data. A successful prediction
algorithm could revolutionize the healthcare industry, as it could preemptively
identify patients with a high risk of hospital admission and reduce the number
of unnecessary hospitalizations. In this work, we implement and optimize a
number of commonly used machine learning algorithms for this problem and
compare their performances to that of an <span class=SpellE>ensembling</span>
algorithm that combines the predictions from all models. We also explore the
effects of feature design and selection methods on these individual models and
their consequent ensemble. We conclude that an ensemble is significantly more
effective than any individual model, reaching position 88 out of 1309 on the
final Heritage Health Prize leaderboard.<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></b></span></p>
